open_questions.title: The .NET Framework
open_questions.description: What is the .NET Framework?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the .NET Framework?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The .NET Framework is a comprehensive software development platform created by Microsoft. It provides a runtime environment called the Common Language Runtime (CLR) and a rich set of class libraries, supporting multiple programming languages like C#, VB .NET, and F# for building various applications on Windows and other platforms with .NET Core and later versions.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The key components of the .NET
open_questions.description: What are the key components of the .NET Framework?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the key components of the .NET Framework?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The two main components are: Common Language Runtime (CLR), which manages the execution of .NET applications by providing services like memory management and security. .NET Class Library (BCL), a vast collection of pre-built classes, interfaces, and types offering a wide range of functionalities.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between value types and
open_questions.description: Explain the difference between value types and reference types in .NET.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the difference between value types and reference types in .NET.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Value types (e.g., int, bool, struct) store their actual data directly in memory, typically on the stack. Each variable holds its own copy of the data. Reference types (e.g., class, string, array) store a reference (memory address) to the actual data, which is located on the heap. Multiple variables can point to the same data in memory.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Managed code in .NET
open_questions.description: What is managed code in .NET?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is managed code in .NET?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Managed code is code that is executed under the control of the Common Language Runtime (CLR). The CLR provides services such as automatic memory management (garbage collection), type safety, and exception handling.Languages like C# and VB .NET compile to managed code.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Boxing and unboxing in .NET.
open_questions.description: Explain boxing and unboxing in .NET.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain boxing and unboxing in .NET.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Boxing is the implicit conversion of a value type to a reference type (specifically, to an object or an interface). The value type is copied onto the heap. Unboxing is the explicit conversion of a reference type back to a value type. It involves checking the type and copying the value from the heap back to the stack.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Garbage collection in .NET
open_questions.description: What is garbage collection in .NET?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is garbage collection in .NET?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Garbage collection is an automatic memory management process performed by the CLR. It periodically identifies and reclaims memory occupied by objects that are no longer referenced by the application, thus preventing memory leaks.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between String and StringBuilder
open_questions.description: What is the difference between String and StringBuilder in C#?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between String and StringBuilder in C#?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: String objects are immutable, meaning their value cannot be changed after creation. Any operation that seems to modify a string actually creates a new String object. StringBuilder is mutable, allowing modifications to the string without creating a new object each time, making it more efficient for frequent string manipulations.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The main principles of Object-Oriented Programming
open_questions.description: What are the main principles of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the main principles of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The four main principles are: Encapsulation: Encapsulation is the principle of bundling data (attributes or properties) and the methods that operate on that data into a single unit, or class. It also involves hiding the internal implementation details of an object and controlling access to its data. Abstraction: Abstraction is the principle of showing only the essential or relevant information to the user while hiding the complex underlying details. It focuses on what an object does rather than how it achieves it, often using abstract classes and interfaces. Inheritance: Inheritance is a mechanism that allows a new class (derived or child class) to inherit properties and behaviors (methods) from an existing class (base or parent class). This promotes code reusability and helps in establishing hierarchical relationships between classes.C# supports single inheritance for classes but multiple inheritance for interfaces. Polymorphism: Polymorphism, meaning "many forms," enables objects of different classes to respond to the same method call in their own specific way. This can be achieved through method overriding and method overloading.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Assemblies in .NET.
open_questions.description: Explain assemblies in .NET.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain assemblies in .NET.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: An assembly is a compiled unit of code (.exe for applications, .dll for libraries) that contains Intermediate Language (IL), metadata (manifest), and resources. It's the basic unit of deployment, versioning, and security in .NET. Assemblies can be private (application-specific) or shared (stored in the Global Assembly Cache - GAC).
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Execution model
open_questions.description: What is Just-In-Time (JIT) compilation?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is Just-In-Time (JIT) compilation?" Requirements: - Answer directly: JS is executed by an engine that compiles/JITs internally - Explain interpreted vs compiled as a spectrum in modern engines - Mention parse -> bytecode -> JIT optimization (high level) - Practical implication: performance varies, warm-up/optimization Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Answer directly: JS is executed by an engine that compiles/JITs internally; Explain interpreted vs compiled as a spectrum in modern engines; Mention parse -> bytecode -> JIT optimization (high level); Practical implication: performance varies, warm-up/optimization. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: JIT compilation is a process where the Common Language Runtime (CLR) converts the Intermediate Language (IL) code of a .NET assembly into native machine code at runtime, just before it's executed. This allows for platform independence while achieving efficient execution.
keyPoints: Answer directly: JS is executed by an engine that compiles/JITs internally
Explain interpreted vs compiled as a spectrum in modern engines
Mention parse -> bytecode -> JIT optimization (high level)
Practical implication: performance varies, warm-up/optimization

referenceAnswers.text: MSIL (also known as CIL - Common Intermediate Language) is a platform-agnostic set of instructions that.NET languages compile to. It's then translated to native code by the JIT compiler when the application is run.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Generics in .NET and their benefits.
open_questions.description: Explain generics in .NET and their benefits.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain generics in .NET and their benefits.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Generics allow you to define type-safe data structures and algorithms without specifying the exact data type at compile time. Type parameters are used as placeholders, and the actual type is specified when the generic type or method is used. Benefits include improved type safety, code reusability, and better performance (by avoiding boxing/unboxing for value types).
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Es exception handling work in .NET
open_questions.description: How does exception handling work in .NET?

Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Exception handling in .NET uses try blocks to enclose code that might throw an exception. catch blocks are used to handle specific types of exceptions that occur in the try block. The optional finally block contains code that is guaranteed to execute regardless of whether an exception occurred or was caught, often used for cleanup operations.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: LINQ (Language Integrated Query) provides a unified syntax within C# to query data from various sources like collections, databases, and XML. It uses a set of extension methods to perform operations like filtering, sorting, and selecting data directly in the code, improving readability and type safety.

open_questions.title: The difference between IEnumerable and IQueryable
open_questions.description: What is the difference between IEnumerable and IQueryable in LINQ, and when to use each?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between IEnumerable and IQueryable in LINQ, and when to use each?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: IEnumerable represents a sequence that can be iterated over, typically used for in-memory collections. Operations on IEnumerable are executed in memory. IQueryable also represents a sequence but is designed for querying data sources outside of memory (like databases). It allows for query translation and execution at the data source, improving performance for large datasets. Use IQueryable when querying databases (e.g., with Entity Framework) and IEnumerable for in-memory collections.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Dependency injection (DI) and its benefits

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Dependency Injection is a design pattern where a class receives its dependencies from an external source rather than creating them itself. This promotes loose coupling, improves testability (by allowing the use of mock objects), increases code reusability, and enhances maintainability.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: .NET Framework was the original Windows-only implementation. .NET Core was a cross-platform, open-source version optimized for modern workloads. .NET 5 and later versions represent a unification of these, aiming for a single platform for all .NET development needs, with ongoing improvements in performance and cross-platform capabilities.

open_questions.title: You handle concurrency and multithreading in

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: .NET provides several ways to handle concurrency, including the Thread class, the Thread Pool, the Task and async/await pattern, the Parallel class for parallel execution, and thread-safe collections in the System.Collections.Concurrent namespace. Proper synchronization mechanisms like locks are crucial to avoid race conditions and deadlocks.

open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain microservices architecture in the context of .NET.?" open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Microservices architecture structures an application as a collection of small, independent services communicating over a network. Benefits include improved scalability, maintainability, fault isolation, and technology diversity. Challenges involve increased complexity in deployment and management, inter-service communication overhead, and the need for robust monitoring. ASP.NET Core is often used to build.NET microservices.

open_questions.title: Different approaches to caching in .NET

open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Describe different approaches to caching in .NET applications and when to use each.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Common caching approaches include: In-memory caching: Fastest, for single-server scenarios. Distributed caching: For scalable, multi-server applications. Client-side caching: HTTP caching, browser storage for static content. Content Delivery Networks (CDNs): For globally distributed static content. The choice depends on data volatility, access patterns, and scalability requirements.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between await AsyncMethod() and
open_questions.description: What is the difference between await AsyncMethod() and AsyncMethod().Result?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between await AsyncMethod() and AsyncMethod().Result?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: await AsyncMethod() is the preferred way to handle asynchronous operations. It pauses the execution of the current async method without blocking the calling thread, allowing it to perform other work. Once the AsyncMethod completes, the execution resumes. AsyncMethod().Result blocks the calling thread until the asynchronous operation completes, which can lead to deadlocks in certain scenarios and should generally be avoided in UI applications or request processing pipelines.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the role of the BackgroundWorker class in multithreaded programming?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The BackgroundWorker class provides a convenient way to perform operations on a separate thread without blocking the user interface (UI) thread in Windows Forms or WPF applications. It simplifies tasks like progress reporting and cancellation.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Es the Task Parallel Library (TPL)
open_questions.description: How does the Task Parallel Library (TPL) improve parallel programming?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How does the Task Parallel Library (TPL) improve parallel programming?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The TPL simplifies parallel programming by providing abstractions like Task and Parallel for executing operations concurrently. It handles task scheduling, load balancing, and synchronization, making it easier to write efficient and scalable parallel code.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of marshaling in .NET.
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of marshaling in .NET.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of marshaling in .NET.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Marshaling is the process of converting data between managed (.NET) and unmanaged (outside the CLR, e.g., COM, Win32 API) memory. It's necessary when interacting with unmanaged code from a .NET application.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: You use the Duplex WCF service
open_questions.description: When would you use the Duplex WCF service?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "When would you use the Duplex WCF service?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Duplex WCF service is used when you need two-way communication between the client and the server, allowing the server to initiate calls back to the client (callbacks). This is useful for scenarios like event notifications or real-time updates where the server needs to push data to the client.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice
